questions.question: Under current GAAP, how many classifications of net assets do not-for-profit organizations use?

options.B: Two
options.C: Three
options.D: Four

questions.explanation: Under ASU 2016-14, not-for-profit organizations classify net assets into two categories: (1) Net assets without donor restrictions and (2) Net assets with donor restrictions. The previous three-category system (unrestricted, temporarily restricted, permanently restricted) was eliminated.
questions.tip: Two categories now: With donor restrictions and Without donor restrictions. Old system had three (unrestricted, temp restricted, perm restricted).

questions.question: An unconditional pledge to contribute $50,000 to a not-for-profit organization should be recognized as:

options.A: Revenue when the pledge is received
options.B: Revenue when the cash is collected
options.C: A liability until the cash is collected
options.D: Revenue when the donor dies

questions.explanation: Unconditional promises to give (pledges) are recognized as revenue when the promise is received, not when cash is collected. The pledge receivable and contribution revenue are recorded at present value if due in more than one year.
questions.tip: Unconditional = recognize immediately. Conditional = wait until condition is substantially met.

questions.question: Which financial statement is required for not-for-profit organizations but NOT for commercial entities?

options.B: Statement of Activities
options.C: Statement of Functional Expenses
options.D: Statement of Cash Flows

questions.explanation: The Statement of Functional Expenses (or equivalent disclosure) is required for NFPs, showing expenses by both natural classification and functional classification. This is unique to NFPs and health care entities.
questions.tip: NFP unique: Statement of Functional Expenses shows expenses by function (program, management, fundraising) and nature (salaries, rent, etc.).

questions.question: Contributed services must be recognized as revenue if they meet which criteria?

options.A: The services have any value to the organization
options.B: The services create or enhance nonfinancial assets or require specialized skills that the organization would otherwise purchase
options.C: The volunteer provides more than 10 hours of service
options.D: The organization requests the services in writing

questions.explanation: Contributed services are recognized if they: (1) create or enhance nonfinancial assets, or (2) require specialized skills (legal, accounting, medical, etc.), are provided by individuals with those skills, and would typically be purchased if not donated.
questions.tip: Specialized skills + would otherwise purchase = recognize. General volunteer time (stuffing envelopes) = do NOT recognize.

questions.question: A donor gives $100,000 to a museum with the stipulation that the funds be used to acquire artwork. This contribution should be classified as:

options.B: Net assets with donor restrictions
options.C: A liability
options.D: Deferred revenue

questions.explanation: The contribution has a purpose restriction (must be used to acquire artwork), making it net assets with donor restrictions. When the artwork is purchased, the restriction is satisfied and a reclassification is made to net assets without donor restrictions.
questions.tip: Donor-imposed purpose or time restriction = Net assets with donor restrictions. No restriction = Without donor restrictions.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a program service expense for a not-for-profit educational institution?

options.B: Administrative salaries
options.C: Classroom instruction costs
options.D: Accounting fees

questions.explanation: Program service expenses are costs directly related to the organization's mission. For an educational institution, classroom instruction costs are program services. Fundraising and administration are supporting services.
questions.tip: Three functional categories: Program services (mission), Management & General (admin), Fundraising. Program costs relate to the exempt purpose.

questions.question: A foundation promises to contribute $200,000 to an NFP if the NFP raises $200,000 in matching funds within two years. After one year, the NFP has raised $150,000. How much contribution revenue should the NFP recognize?
questions.explanation: This is a conditional contribution because there is a barrier (raise matching funds) that must be overcome. Until the condition is substantially met ($200,000 raised), no revenue is recognized. The $150,000 raised is progress but doesn't trigger recognition.
questions.tip: Conditional = barrier + right of return/release. Wait until barrier is substantially overcome to recognize revenue.

questions.question: A donor establishes a permanent endowment of $1,000,000 with a not-for-profit, stipulating that principal must be maintained and only income can be used for scholarships. How should this gift be classified?

options.B: Net assets with donor restrictions – time restricted
options.C: Net assets with donor restrictions – perpetual in nature
options.D: A liability until earnings are distributed

questions.explanation: A permanent endowment where the principal must be maintained in perpetuity is classified as net assets with donor restrictions that are perpetual in nature. The earnings may be restricted or unrestricted depending on donor stipulation.
questions.tip: Perpetual restrictions (endowments) are a subset of 'with donor restrictions.' The old term 'permanently restricted' is now 'perpetual in nature.'

questions.question: An NFP receives an unconditional pledge of $100,000 per year for 3 years. The discount rate is 5%. What should be recorded as contribution revenue in year 1? (PV factor for annuity of 3 years at 5% = 2.723)
questions.explanation: Multi-year pledges are recorded at present value. Revenue = $100,000 × 2.723 = $272,300. In subsequent years, the discount amortization is recorded as additional contribution revenue.
questions.tip: Multi-year pledges: Record at PV when received. Interest accretion in later years is contribution revenue, not interest income.

questions.question: An NFP received a time-restricted gift of $50,000 in Year 1 to be used in Year 2. In Year 2, the organization spent the funds. What entry is required in Year 2?

options.B: Debit expense, Credit cash
options.C: Debit net assets with donor restrictions, Credit net assets without donor restrictions (reclassification)
options.D: Debit contribution revenue, Credit cash

questions.explanation: When a time or purpose restriction is satisfied, a reclassification is made from net assets with donor restrictions to net assets without donor restrictions. This is shown on the Statement of Activities as 'Net assets released from restrictions.'
questions.tip: Restriction satisfied → Reclassify: Debit With Restrictions, Credit Without Restrictions. The expense is recorded separately against unrestricted.

questions.question: A pharmaceutical company donates medications with a fair value of $500,000 to a healthcare NFP. The NFP uses the medications in its programs. How should this be recorded?

options.A: Contribution revenue and inventory at cost to the donor
options.B: Contribution revenue and inventory at fair value
options.C: No entry until medications are used
options.D: A liability until medications are distributed

questions.explanation: Contributed nonfinancial assets (in-kind gifts) are recorded at fair value at the date of gift. The NFP records contribution revenue and either inventory or expense (if used immediately) at the $500,000 fair value.
questions.tip: In-kind gifts at FV. Note: ASU 2020-07 requires specific disclosures about contributed nonfinancial assets.

questions.question: An NFP receives $75,000 to pass through to another specified organization with no variance power. How should the NFP record this receipt?

options.B: A liability of $75,000
options.C: Contribution revenue with donor restriction
options.D: An agency transaction with no revenue effect

questions.explanation: When an NFP receives funds to pass through to a specified beneficiary and has no variance power (cannot redirect the funds), it acts as an agent. The receipt is recorded as a liability, not revenue. When disbursed, the liability is reduced.
questions.tip: Agent vs. donee: If no variance power and beneficiary specified = agent (liability). If variance power or beneficiary not specified = revenue.

questions.question: An NFP professional association collects annual membership dues of $24,000 from a member on January 1 for the calendar year membership. As of March 31, how much should be recognized as revenue?
questions.explanation: Membership dues that provide benefits over a period should be recognized ratably over the membership period. 3 months / 12 months × $24,000 = $6,000. The remaining $18,000 is deferred revenue.
questions.tip: Exchange portion of dues: recognize over period. Contribution portion (if any): recognize when received.

questions.question: A donor establishes a charitable remainder annuity trust naming an NFP as the remainder beneficiary. The trust assets are $500,000, the annuity to the donor is $30,000/year for life, and the present value of the remainder interest is $320,000. What does the NFP record at inception?

options.B: Contribution revenue of $320,000
options.C: Contribution revenue of $30,000
options.D: No entry until the donor dies

questions.explanation: When an NFP is the remainder beneficiary of a charitable remainder trust, it recognizes contribution revenue equal to the present value of its expected future benefit ($320,000), not the full trust assets.
questions.tip: Split-interest agreements: Record PV of the NFP's beneficial interest. Adjust annually for changes in actuarial assumptions.

questions.question: A corporation pays $100,000 to an NFP for a table sponsorship at a gala dinner. The fair value of the dinner and benefits received is $15,000. How should the NFP record this transaction?

options.B: Contribution revenue of $100,000
options.C: Exchange revenue of $15,000 and contribution revenue of $85,000
options.D: Contribution revenue of $15,000 and exchange revenue of $85,000

questions.explanation: This is a quid pro quo transaction. The portion equal to fair value of benefits provided ($15,000) is exchange revenue; the excess ($85,000) is a contribution. The NFP must disclose the amount deductible as a charitable contribution.
questions.tip: Quid pro quo: Separate exchange portion (FV of goods/services) from contribution portion (excess payment).

questions.question: An NFP receives a cost-reimbursement grant from the government for $300,000 to provide job training. In Year 1, the NFP incurs $200,000 of eligible costs. How much grant revenue should be recognized in Year 1?
questions.explanation: Cost-reimbursement grants are conditional contributions. Revenue is recognized when conditions are met (eligible costs incurred). Since $200,000 of eligible expenses were incurred, $200,000 of grant revenue is recognized.
questions.tip: Cost-reimbursement grants are conditional. Revenue = qualifying expenditures incurred, up to grant amount.

questions.question: On an NFP's Statement of Activities, expenses are reported:

options.A: As decreases in net assets with donor restrictions
options.B: As decreases in net assets without donor restrictions
options.C: Split between restricted and unrestricted based on funding source
options.D: As direct reductions of contribution revenue

questions.explanation: Expenses are always reported as decreases in net assets without donor restrictions. Donor restrictions affect how contributions are reported, but when the funds are spent, the related restriction is released and the expense reduces unrestricted net assets.
questions.tip: All expenses reduce net assets without donor restrictions. Release restrictions first (reclassification), then record expense against unrestricted.

questions.question: An NFP's board of directors designates $500,000 of unrestricted funds for future building improvements. How should this be classified?

options.B: Net assets without donor restrictions with disclosure of the designation
options.C: A liability for future construction
options.D: A separate board-designated net asset category

questions.explanation: Board designations are internal designations, not donor restrictions. The funds remain classified as net assets without donor restrictions. The designation should be disclosed but does not change the classification.
questions.tip: Board designation ≠ donor restriction. Still report as 'without donor restrictions' but may disclose the board's intent.

questions.question: A museum purchases artwork for $2,000,000 for its permanent collection. The collection meets the definition of a collection under GAAP. The museum must:

options.A: Capitalize the artwork and depreciate it
options.B: Capitalize the artwork without depreciation
options.C: Either capitalize the artwork or expense it with disclosure, but must be consistent
options.D: Always expense collection items when acquired

questions.explanation: NFPs have a policy choice for collections: capitalize (with or without depreciation, if inexhaustible) OR not capitalize and expense acquisitions. Whichever policy is chosen must be applied consistently with required disclosures.
questions.tip: Collections meeting GAAP definition: Capitalize OR don't capitalize (expense). Must apply policy consistently. Retroactive capitalization not required.

questions.question: An NFP holds a charity auction that generates $80,000 in revenue. Direct costs of the event are $25,000. How should this be reported on the Statement of Activities?

options.B: Gross revenue of $80,000 and gross expenses of $25,000
options.C: Contribution revenue of $80,000 only
options.D: Fundraising expense of $25,000 only

questions.explanation: Special events should be reported at gross amounts—revenue and direct costs separately. The direct costs are typically shown either as fundraising expense or as a direct offset to special event revenue with the net shown, but gross presentation is preferred.
questions.tip: Report special event revenue and direct costs separately (gross). Can show direct costs as offset to revenue with net disclosed.

questions.question: Under ASU 2016-14, NFPs must disclose:

options.B: Qualitative and quantitative information about liquidity and availability of resources
options.C: A full cash flow forecast for the next year
options.D: Only board-designated amounts

questions.explanation: ASU 2016-14 requires NFPs to provide qualitative information about how they manage liquidity and quantitative information about financial assets available within one year to meet general expenditures.
questions.tip: Liquidity disclosure: Qualitative (how liquidity is managed) + Quantitative (financial assets available within 1 year for general expenditures).

questions.question: An NFP's executive director spends 60% of time on program activities, 30% on administration, and 10% on fundraising. The director's $150,000 salary should be allocated:

options.B: $90,000 program, $45,000 M&G, $15,000 fundraising
options.C: 100% to program services
options.D: $75,000 program, $75,000 supporting services

questions.explanation: Expenses that benefit multiple functions should be allocated using a reasonable method. Time spent is a common allocation basis. Program = $150,000 × 60% = $90,000; M&G = $150,000 × 30% = $45,000; Fundraising = $150,000 × 10% = $15,000.
questions.tip: Allocate shared costs using reasonable, consistent methodology. Common bases: time, space, FTEs, direct costs.

questions.question: An NFP has a donor-restricted endowment with an original gift value of $1,000,000. Due to market losses, the fair value is now $920,000. How should this be reported?

options.A: Report $920,000 in net assets without donor restrictions
options.B: Report $1,000,000 with donor restrictions and $80,000 deficit in unrestricted
options.C: Report the $920,000 fair value in net assets with donor restrictions
options.D: Remove the endowment from the financial statements

questions.explanation: Under ASU 2016-14, underwater endowments (where fair value is below the original gift amount) are reported entirely in net assets with donor restrictions. The deficiency is not reclassified to unrestricted. Disclosures about underwater endowments are required.
questions.tip: Underwater endowment: Report at FV within 'with donor restrictions.' Disclose original gift amount and deficiency in notes.

questions.question: Which characteristic most clearly indicates a transfer is a contribution rather than an exchange transaction?

options.B: The recipient is a not-for-profit
options.C: There is no expectation of proportionate value in return
options.D: The transfer is recurring annually

questions.explanation: The key distinction between a contribution and exchange transaction is whether the resource provider expects proportionate value in return. Contributions are nonreciprocal transfers where the donor does not receive equal value in exchange.
questions.tip: Contribution = nonreciprocal (donor gets nothing or less than proportionate value). Exchange = reciprocal (commensurate value exchanged).

questions.question: An NFP receives unconditional pledges of $500,000. Based on historical experience, 10% of pledges are expected to be uncollectible. Net pledge revenue recorded should be:

options.B: $450,000 (net of allowance)
options.C: $0 until collected
options.D: $500,000 less a contra-liability

questions.explanation: Pledges are recorded at their net realizable value. Gross pledges of $500,000 less 10% allowance for uncollectible pledges ($50,000) = $450,000 net contribution revenue.
questions.tip: Record pledges at net realizable value. Allowance for uncollectibles reduces the receivable and revenue recognized.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a private foundation that distinguishes it from a public charity?

options.B: It typically receives support from a limited number of sources
options.C: It must file Form 990
options.D: It cannot receive contributions

questions.explanation: Private foundations typically receive support from a single source or limited sources (family, corporation), while public charities receive broad public support. Both are 501(c)(3), but private foundations face more restrictions and excise taxes.
questions.tip: Private foundation: Limited funding sources, subject to excise taxes, must distribute 5% annually. Public charity: Broad support, fewer restrictions.

questions.question: Under UPMIFA (as adopted by most states), an NFP may spend from an endowment fund:

options.B: Only income such as dividends and interest
options.C: Amounts prudent considering the fund's purposes and the organization's needs
options.D: Only amounts specifically authorized by the original donor

questions.explanation: UPMIFA allows spending from endowments based on a prudent standard considering factors such as the fund's purposes, preservation of purchasing power, economic conditions, and the organization's overall resources and needs.
questions.tip: UPMIFA: Prudence standard for spending. Consider multiple factors. Replaces historical dollar value maintenance requirement.

questions.question: An NFP sends a mailing that includes an educational message about health issues and a request for donations. For joint costs to be allocated to program expense, which criteria must be met?

options.A: The mailing must be sent to previous donors only
options.B: Purpose, audience, and content criteria must all be met
options.C: The fundraising request must be less than 50% of the mailing
options.D: The educational content must be reviewed by an independent party

questions.explanation: Under ASC 958-720, joint costs can be allocated to program only if all three criteria are met: (1) Purpose criterion - accomplishes program objectives, (2) Audience criterion - selected based on need for program content, (3) Content criterion - calls to action that support program goals.
questions.tip: All 3 criteria required: Purpose (program function), Audience (need-based selection), Content (specific call to action). If any fails, all costs = fundraising.

questions.question: An NFP is named as an irrevocable beneficiary of a charitable lead trust held by an independent trustee. The present value of the expected distributions is $400,000. The NFP should record:

options.B: A beneficial interest asset and contribution revenue of $400,000
options.C: A receivable and deferred revenue of $400,000
options.D: A footnote disclosure only

questions.explanation: When an NFP has an unconditional right to receive benefits from a trust held by a third party, it recognizes an asset (beneficial interest in trust) and contribution revenue at the present value of expected future benefits.
questions.tip: Irrevocable beneficial interest held by third party: Record asset and contribution revenue at PV. Adjust periodically for changes in estimates.

questions.question: A not-for-profit healthcare organization provides $2,000,000 of services to patients who qualify for charity care (measured at charges). How should this be reported?

options.A: As revenue with an offsetting bad debt expense
options.B: As revenue with an offsetting contractual adjustment
options.C: Not as revenue; disclosed in the notes at cost
options.D: As contribution revenue received from patients

questions.explanation: Charity care does not qualify as revenue because there is no expectation of payment. It is not recorded as revenue or receivable. Instead, the cost of charity care is disclosed in the notes, along with the organization's charity care policy.
questions.tip: Charity care ≠ revenue (no expectation of payment). Disclose charity care policy and cost in notes. Different from bad debts (expected payment).

questions.question: Two not-for-profit organizations of similar size combine in a merger of equals with neither being the acquirer. Under ASC 958-805, this is accounted for as:

options.B: A merger using carryover basis
options.C: Pooling of interests
options.D: A combination using the equity method

questions.explanation: NFP combinations can be either a merger (carryover basis, no acquirer) or an acquisition (fair value, acquirer identified). A merger of equals uses carryover basis for all assets and liabilities with no goodwill recognized.
questions.tip: NFP combinations: Merger = carryover basis, no goodwill. Acquisition = fair value, goodwill possible. Determine if acquirer exists.

questions.question: An NFP receives a $900,000 gift restricted for building construction. In Year 1, the NFP capitalizes the building at $900,000. The building has a 30-year life. The donor did not stipulate how long the building must be used. What reclassification occurs in Year 1?

options.B: Reclassify $900,000 from restricted to unrestricted when construction is complete
options.C: No reclassification; keep $900,000 in restricted permanently
options.D: Either reclassify in full when placed in service OR over the asset's useful life (policy choice)

questions.explanation: For gifts restricted for acquisition of long-lived assets, the NFP chooses a policy: (1) Release restriction when asset is placed in service (reclassify full amount), or (2) Release over the asset's useful life (matches depreciation). Policy must be consistent.
questions.tip: Gifts for capital assets: Policy choice for release timing. Either all at once when placed in service, or ratably over useful life.

questions.question: An NFP has the following: Contribution revenue without restrictions $800,000; Contribution revenue with restrictions $300,000; Program expenses $600,000; Supporting expenses $200,000; Net assets released from restrictions $150,000. What is the change in net assets without donor restrictions?

options.C: $150,000 increase

questions.explanation: Change in unrestricted = Unrestricted revenues + Releases - Expenses = $800,000 + $150,000 - $600,000 - $200,000 = $150,000 increase. The $300,000 restricted contribution affects restricted net assets, not unrestricted.
questions.tip: Unrestricted change = Unrestricted revenue + Releases from restriction - All expenses. Restricted change = Restricted revenue - Releases.

questions.question: A donor establishes a $1,000,000 endowment with instructions that principal be maintained and income be used for scholarships. In Year 1, the endowment earns $40,000 dividends and $60,000 unrealized gains. How should the $100,000 total return be classified?

options.A: All $100,000 in net assets with donor restrictions
options.B: $40,000 without restrictions, $60,000 with restrictions
options.C: Classification depends on state law (UPMIFA) and any donor stipulations regarding gains
options.D: All $100,000 in net assets without donor restrictions

questions.explanation: Classification of endowment returns depends on (1) explicit donor stipulations about gains, (2) state law (UPMIFA), and (3) the organization's interpretation. If donor is silent on gains, state law governs. Returns may be restricted or unrestricted.
questions.tip: Endowment returns: Check donor stipulation first, then state law. Donor can restrict gains; if silent, state law (usually UPMIFA) applies.

questions.question: An NFP university receives a $5,000,000 research grant from a pharmaceutical company. In exchange, the university will conduct specified research and the company will receive exclusive rights to any patents developed. How should this be accounted for?

options.B: Contribution revenue with donor restrictions
options.C: Exchange revenue under ASC 606, recognized as performance obligations are satisfied
options.D: Deferred revenue until research is complete

questions.explanation: This is an exchange transaction because the company receives commensurate value (exclusive patent rights). It's accounted for under ASC 606, with revenue recognized as the research performance obligation is satisfied over time or at a point in time.
questions.tip: Sponsored research with IP rights to funder = exchange transaction (ASC 606). Without IP rights = likely contribution. Analyze what funder receives.
